. @gaffer01 while the legal implications of having a "3rd party contributor license" that must be signed presumably makes bureaucratic sense internally to GCHQ, externally it is clunky and unfortunate. Is it not possible for you to safely and securely make code review of submitted PRs, and conduct appropriate testing and analysis of submissions, and have the correct licence information that ensures your outright ownership of all contributed code?
If you start this process by putting up barriers (however small) to contribution, the friction you create will ensure that eventually your open source projects will be replaced and ultimately forgotten by history, because open-sourcing in a productive manner is more than simply opening access to source code, and using Github as a release mechanism.
Many great open source projects have good developer guidelines that explain what you expect and demand for contribs to be considered, and if you were able to run it like that, with implicit agreement to the T&Cs of submission it would really make a substantial difference.
. @gaffer01 I hope you are thinking of ways you can move away from this simplistic publication model, and into a more collaborative mode. I understand it's all happening within an organisation that has thousands of internal barriers to collaboratively working on software in an open community, but without that mutual trust, you haven't built any trust, just gave us a tool, which is fine, but ultimately disappointing and not worthy of the same excitement that most other interesting OS projects command.

iand:
In the UK, government funded work is under Crown Copyright rather than public domain. Crown Copyright has almost no restrictions except the government retains copyright. In practice this is as reusable as it would be if it were in the public domain but, in principle, the government can enforce copyright if it wanted to, which some might say could happen if the government wanted to manufacturer a legal position against a particular group or individual.
An agency can additionally state that the work is available under the Open Government Licence which is compatible with the Creative Commons Attribution license. I encourage the owners of the Gaffer repository to state that the code and documentation is also available under the OGL by following the guidance here
.

. The point is that initialising a graph with particular store properties should cause that store to be instantiated. Only initialising it when addElements is called leads to problems when multiple parallel processes simultaneously start writing to a new store.

. Agreed. In general stores should return their results lazily, e.g. if the user queries for a node which has a lot of edges, those edges shouldn't be materialised into a set and then returned. Instead, edges should be read from the underlying data storage as the user consumes them by reading through the iterable. The ArrayList store materialises the set, which should be discouraged and so should be changed to return results lazily. I'll raise a separate issue about this.
. It looks like both ends of the edge are checked to see if they are in the Bloom filter. Really it is only necessary to check the non-query end of the edge (i.e. the second one in the rowkey). Checking the query end as well will increase the number of false positives.
. Can you clarify what this behaviour means? What is the first edge returned, i.e. what does (A-B+A-C) mean, what is the source and what is the destination?
This behaviour is not generally what is wanted from a range scan. Generally from a range scan you would just want those 3 edges returned. Is it possible to turn the behaviour described above off (and still do aggregation of the values over column family and visibility)?
If the data was:
A-1 GROUP1 Count 1
A-2 GROUP2 Count 2
A-3 GROUP1 Count 1
A-4 GROUP2 Count 2
...
A-1000000 GROUP1 Count 1
A-1000001 GROUP2 Count 2
then the the aggregated edge would contain a lot of data (i.e. whatever A-B+A-C means would be large), and if there were a lot of groups then a lot of data would need to be cached before it could be output.
In general this breaks the idea that the iterators read data, aggregating into one element, then when the next group is reached, the element is output - it's a very low state process.
Does this behaviour work across tablets? A-C might be in a different tablet (and on a different tablet server) to A-B. Does the aggregation work in this case?
. The most common use case for range scans is to return all edges for vertices in a certain range, doing standard aggregation of properties over column qualifier (e.g. different time windows), e.g. if the graph is:
A->B GROUP1 date=20160101 count=10
A->B GROUP1 date=20160102 count=20
A->C GROUP1 date=20160101 count=5
B->E GROUP1 date=20160101 count=2
B->E GROUP1 date=20160102 count=3
C->F GROUP1 date=20160101 count=2
C->F GROUP1 date=20160102 count=4
D->G GROUP1 date=20160101 count=1
and we specify a range of B to C, the desired edges are:
B->E GROUP1 date=20160101-02 count=5
C->F GROUP1 date=20160101-02 count=6
From what you say, this is not currently supported and is not the standard meaning of doing aggregation in a range scan?
"Currently all aggregation assumes that all data for the provided ranges lives on the same tablet server, client side aggregation is needed for all cases of aggregation to catch cases where the desired ranges are split across tablet servers."
Is the client side aggregation implemented? If not then the current implementation will not always work and needs fixing.

The versioning iterator should be turned off and no aggregator iterator added.

The HLLMap looks interesting. A typical use of HLL in Gaffer is to store a HLL on each node in the graph which allows for a quick estimate of the degree of a node. The comments on HLLMap say that it is optimised for many millions of keys - does it have any advantages if the number of keys is small, e.g. if there was a need to store several (<5) HLLs on each node, would HLLMap offer a storage advantage over just storing a map from key to HLL?

As the documentation for HLLMap notes, for datasets where the number of values per key is power-law, the storage cost is dominated by the large number of keys which have a small number of values. It is crucial for the serialisation of a HLL which is almost empty to be very efficient. HLlSketch seems to serialise to 73 bytes even if nothing has been added to it. Is there any way to improve that? One option might be to have an object which accepts items but internally only actually creates a HLL once a certain number of items have been added, e.g. if only one string of length 10 has been added then it would be more efficient to store that than the HLL. If more items are added later then internally a HLL could be created and the previous items added to that.. Thanks for all these comments.
I can see the advantage of HllMap. Being able to derive other sketches from it is really nice as well. Within Gaffer, nodes can have multiple properties, and the underlying store typically serialises these into a value, with the key being the serialised node. To use HllMap within a store we'd need to store some of the properties on the node, and all the HLLs in the HllMap. It's not impossible to do this, but it doesn't fit into the current Gaffer stores at the moment. The HllMap could of course be used in a streaming setting before data reaches the graph.

The HllMap was designed for fixed length keys (identifiers), which was critical for efficient map storage and speed.

The fixed size of the key is understandable. It makes it a little harder to use as we support arbitrary objects as our nodes, so we'd have to hash those into a fixed length byte array to generate the key, ensuring that the array is long enough to avoid collisions, but that's ok.

All of our sketches have a "warm-up" mode where the sketch starts out very small and grows larger only as required by the data.

It makes sense that the updateable form of the sketches requires more storage space than the compressed ones. The challenge for our framework is that it supports aggregation of properies (e.g. merging of two HLL sketches), and that merging can happen a long time after the sketch was last updated. Therefore we need to be able to serialise the sketch, leave it stored in the underlying key-value store for a long period, and then at some point deserialise it, merge the new item in, and then reserialise it. Of course, this is inefficient in comparison to simply leaving the sketch in memory, but that's not always possible.

If it could then we would get the advantages of the compact serialisation and retain the ability to merge 2 sketches later.
. @leerho Thanks again for these comments.
When using sketches to estimate the degree of a node, the primary concern is compact serialisation, as there will be one sketch per node (or one per node per time window if the properties are stored keyed on some time window). The creation, update, and serialisation speed, and on-heap space, are of secondary importance. As discussed before, in a power-law graph the majority of nodes have low degree so compact serialisation for the low cardinality case is particularly important. Ideally the sketch should provide accurate estimates for both low cardinalities and high cardinalities. It's worth noting that for large-scale graphs a small sketch size might be chosen at the expense of accuracy, i.e. prioritise small serialised size over the accuracy of the sketch.
If the HLL implementation could be extended so that it allowed merging of the compact sketches, that would make it a lot more useful for this application. Presumably by "advanced estimators" you're referring to the improvements in the HyperLogLog++ paper? Look forward to seeing the improved HLL code in due course - please raise an issue here if you want us to test it.
Set intersections using theta sketches are of interest, and are supported by our framework - theta sketches can be added to nodes or edges. But serialisers and aggregators to allow these to be used have only recently been added so it's not yet clear how widely they will be used. One use case for the theta sketches would be to understand the evolution of the graph over time. For example, maintain a theta sketch of the edges added to the graph for each day, and then perform sketch intersections to understand what proportion of edges added one day had already been added the previous day. This use case only requires one sketch to be stored per day, so serialised space is not important, but update speed would be very important as the sketch would be updated many times.. > So if merging of mixed k sketches is very common, you may as well choose space or accuracy to determine k, and stick with it for all scales.
Generally, the same k is used for all the sketches in an application.

if your cardinality distribution is power-law, you might consider using the p-sampling option of the Theta Sketches

Thanks - we weren't aware of that option. We should investigate that.

We also have developed advanced estimators for the low and intermediate cardinality zones that has not yet been published (coming soon).

Reopening so that it's easier to see the discussion is on-going.. @leerho We've briefly experimented with the new version of HLLSketch. Here are some simple observations - these mostly won't be a surprise to you:

In terms of the serialised size of HLLSketch, as the number of items added increases there's a transition point. Once at or past the transition point, the serialised size is predictable (e.g. 2^k + 40 for TgtHllType.HLL_8).
The point at which the transition occurs increases as k increases.
The estimate up to the transition point appears to be perfect.
Serialisation size for small sets: it takes 8 bytes to store an empty HllSketch, then approximately 4 bytes per item, up to the transition point to the full sketch.
It is easy to merge HLLSketchs using the Union. The Union has a toByteArray method but there doesn't seem to be a way to deserialise it back from that byte array - is there a way?
Comparison with the HyperLogLogPlus class from the com.clearspring.analytics:stream library:
As small serialised size is more important than absolute accuracy, we compared the smallest versions of each (namely HyperLogLogPlus(4,4) with HLLSketch(7, TgtHllType.HLL_4)). Here size is the number of items added, CS=clearspring, DS=DataSketches, the number of bytes is the serialised size and the percentage error is the difference between the estimated size and the actual size:
Size 0: CS - 8 bytes, DS - 8 bytes
Size 2: CS - 12 bytes (0% error), DS - 16 bytes (0% error)
Size 100000: CS - 20 bytes (0.25% error), DS - 104 bytes (12% error)
Size 200000: CS - 20 bytes (24% error), DS - 104 bytes (0.02%)
Size 1000000: CS - 20 bytes (34% error), DS - 104 bytes (2.6% error)
The size of the error from DS at size 100000 is surprisingly large, much larger than when more items are added which is odd.
In power-law situations, there won't be many large sets, therefore the additional size likely doesn't matter, and the additional size of small sketches (e.g. 16 bytes vs 12 bytes) may or may not matter). Is is possible to have smaller HLLSketchs than HLLSketch(7, TgtHllType.HLL_4)?

I've rerun the comparison between DataSketches and clearspring using HyperLogLogPlus(7) and HLLSketch(7, TgtHllType.HLL_4):

Size 100000: CS - 96 bytes (13.5% error), DS - 104 bytes (12% error)
Size 200000: CS - 96 bytes (7.8% error), DS - 104 bytes (0.02%)
Size 1000000: CS - 96 bytes (3.8% error), DS - 104 bytes (2.6% error)

So DataSketches is more accurate - by a very large amount for size 200000, by a small amount for size 100000 (but as discussed the 12% error seems anomalous) and by a moderate amount at size 1000000.

Here's a summary of the use of sketches from Data Sketches in Gaffer - there are a couple of questions in there to check we're using it in the optimal way.
For any sketch that we use we need to be able to serialise it to a byte array for storage. Later we need to be able to deserialise it (a) back to the sketch to obtain whatever estimates the sketch provides, (b) to merge it with another deserialised sketch. Of course this serialisation and deserialisation can be relatively expensive, but as some of our stores (e.g. the Accumulo and Hbase ones) are designed for large-scale storage, it is not always viable to leave the sketches in memory. Streaming jobs can be used to aggregate sketches over a time window before they are serialised and stored, but the requirement to deserialise them later and possibly merge with other sketches of the same type remains.
Sketch: HyperLogLog
    Typically used to obtain quick estimates of the degree of a vertex (by putting a HyperLogLog sketch on each vertex - the HLL contains all the vertices at other ends of edges from the vertex). The com.yahoo.sketches.hll.Union class is used for this. It is serialised with the toCompactByteArray() method, deserialised with Union.heapify(bytes), and two Unions a and b are merged using a.update(b.getResult()).
    Question: Would it be more efficient to use the static method unionImpl on Union to merge the two Unions (but this method is not public so presumably it is not intended to be used by external code)?
Sketch: ReservoirItemsUnion
    Example use-cases: Maintain a random sample of some property on a node or edge. This is used in the BoundedTimestampSet class to maintain a random sample of the timestamps a node or edge was seen active. It could also be used to store a random sample of the neighbours of a vertex on the vertex.
    Classes ReservoirLongsUnion and ReservoirItemsUnion are used for this. They are serialised with the toByteArray method, deserialised with heapify(WritableMemory.wrap(bytes), SERIALISER) method, and two Unions a and b are merged using a.update(b.getResult()).
        Question: is this the best way? Should it be done with a.update(Memory.wrap(b.toByteArray()))?
Sketch: Quantiles
    Example use-cases: Estimate the percentiles of some numerical property that is associated to a vertex or edge. 
    Classes ItemsUnion and DoublesUnion are used for this. They are serialised with union.getResult().toByteArray() method (it seems that there is no toByteArray directly on Union, unlike the reservoir sampling package?), deserialised with DoublesUnion union = DoublesUnion.builder().build();
        union.update(WritableMemory.wrap(bytes)); and two Unions a and b are merged using a.update(b.getResult()).
Sketch: Frequencies
    Example use-case: Estimate the frequency with which a long property is seen on a vertex or edge.
    Classes ItemsSketch and LongsSketch are used for this. They are serialised with toByteArray(), deserialised with getInstance(WritableMemory.wrap(bytes)) and two sketches a and b are merged using a.merge(b).
Sketch: Theta
    Example use-case: Estimate the number of distinct edges seen on Jan 1st, the number seen on Jan 2nd and the number in common between those two days.
    Class com.yahoo.sketches.theta.Union is used for this. It is serialised with union.getResult().toByteArray(), and deserialised with Union union = Sketches.setOperationBuilder().buildUnion(); union.update(WritableMemory.wrap(bytes));, and two sketches a and b are merged using a.update(b.getResult()).

Thanks for asking that question (i.e. why do we use Unions not sketches). It's a fundamental question and probably worth revisiting.
Our main requirement is to be able to aggregate two serialised properties together, where the property is either a sketch or a union. As we use a union, to aggregate two of them a and b, we can just do
a.update(b.getResult());

If we were using sketches we would have to do something like:
ReservoirLongsUnion union = ReservoirLongsUnion.newInstance(10);
union.update(a);
union.update(b);
ReservoirLongsSketch merged = union.getResult();

In the first approach, we need to call getResult() once and update once. In the second we need to create a new Union, call update twice and then call getResult().
Although we will often be merging more than two of these together (although generally only a few of these per node or vertex, not millions), the aggregation API requires the result of the aggregation to be of the same type as the things being aggregated. So when using sketches (2nd code snippet) we would have to repeatedly get the result from the union, and then create another union when the next item for the same vertex/node needed to be merged.
There was also some issue, which I can't remember in detail, about some of the sketches 
not being updateable once they have been serialised to a compact form.
If this doesn't make sense, or you think that using Unions is the wrong approach, please let us know.. @AlexanderSaydakov

The operation should not be called Path. It should be called GetPaths and should return Paths.
We need a Path class that can be used to store a path through the graph. A Path is more than just an Iterable of Edges as there is a guarantee that one of the vertices in the next edge is the same as one of the vertices in the current Edge. The Path class should enforce this constraint when it is created.
Are we going to use the MatchedVertex field in a Path to identify which end of the edge was either the seed (if it's the first edge) or appeared in the previous edge (if it's not the first edge)? If so the Path class should enforce this.
What Paths are valid? Is A->B->A valid? Is A->B->A->C valid? Is A->B->A->B valid?
A Path class could include just Edges, or include both Entities and Edges. We should allow the user to decide which they want. This would then mean that the GetPath operation with only 1 hop could return Entitys for the seed vertex, Edges and then Entitys for the destination vertex (currently users have to manually query to find the properties of vertices at the other end of a hop).
Creating multiple GetElements operations as the input to the operation gives maximum flexibility to the user but is complicated if all you want to do is run multiple GetEdges. There could be another operation called GetNHopPaths which did this automatically.. Thanks. The other advantage of having a Path object is that it can have methods to return the vertex at "distance" N from the original seed. This avoids the user having to iterate through the list of Edges until N have been consumed and then use MatchedVertex to find the actual distance N vertex.

It might be worth thinking if there is some object that wraps an Iterable of Paths that would support methods like getVerticesAtDistance(n) - that could then be used to return all vertices at distance N from some seeds.. We should be careful about whether our Path object is actually a trail or a walk: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path_(graph_theory).
In a directed graph A->B->C there is a path A->B->C but there is no path C<-B<-A. But with the current proposed implementation of this operation, C<-B<-A would be returned as path from the seed C.
We need to:
- Be clear about whether we're creating walks, trails, or paths.
- Be clear whether we're treating the graph as undirected (so that C-B-A is a valid path in the above example) or respecting the edge directions (so that it isn't a valid path).. The way this should work is:

Validation should be applied to all elements when new data is added (as all the data has to be read anyway) - this should be optional though in case your application knows for sure that no invalid data has been added.
There should be a RemoveInvalidElements operation that reprocesses the entire graph and removes invalid elements.

All queries against the Parquet store should have an optional option to validate the data before it is returned. There are scenarios where you know there isn't any invalid data, e.g. you do a nightly update to the graph which adds new data and removes old data and you then know that all queries that run in the next 24 hours won't see any invalid data (because all the data in the graph is now valid for the next 24 hours). In this case you want to avoid the expense of validation (the additional expense of doing validation could be very high if you're getting a data frame and then only reading one column - doing validation may require reading all the columns, converting to a Java Element object and applying a predicate).. I don't think there's any need for an option to set the number of reducers. It's best to use one reducer for each tablet, and this should be the default. Early versions of Gaffer didn't have the option to set the number of reducers, and this was based on Accumulo's recommended approach.
The times that isn't the best idea are described in the documentation, quoted below. Suggest we remove (or deprecate) the option to set the number of reducers.
If there's believed to be a bug in the logic for using the minimum and maximum numbers, then can this be explained here, as it was tested fairly carefully when it was added.

By default the number of reducers used in the MapReduce job that converts data into the correct form is the same as the number of tablets. There are at least two scenarios where this is not ideal. First, if a large amount of data is being added into a table with a small number of tablets, then the number of reducers will be too small (i.e. each reducer will have a very large amount of work to do). Second, if a small amount of data is being added into a table with a large number of tablets, then the number of reducers will be too great, and there will be a large amount of unnecessary task creation. There are two options on the AddElementsFromHdfs operation that can be used to set the minimum and maximum number of reducers that are used in the MapReduce job. This bug was fixed during the major rewrite of the Parquet store in #1884 .. The only possible issue is that if you have different vertex types for source and destination in an undirected edge then we may use the wrong serialiser, e.g. if the source is a string and the destination is an integer, then if they're flipped when an edge is created, we may try to use a string serialiser for the integer. If the user specifies the source is a string and the destination is an integer, and they specify different serialisers for those, then there may be issues serialising / deserialising. Options:
Leave it as is and document that if you use different types in undirected edges your serialiser has to deal with that, or else it breaks;
Not allow schemas with different types for the source and destination in undirected edges (but I'm not sure we can do that - the directed field is just a type and we may not know when that is always false);
Spot situations where the serialiser for the source and destination in an undirected edge are different and automatically add information to the serialisation that specifies which was used (but again we can't always tell from the schema whether an edge could be undirected - it could be of type "myBooleanType" which is of class Boolean and not have any validation logic - then we don't know whether it's undirected or not).. kfogel:
Thanks, @gaffer01.  What I was really asking is what is the publication boundary -- that is, given the above, why not do the work in an open repository starting from the beginning?
. Hmm.  There's a lot of speculation in this thread as to the reasons GCHQ isn't doing the work in the open in the first place.  Only @gaffer01 can say for sure which reasons are correct and which aren't, but if it were just a matter of code having to be audited before being published, the usual method for solving that -- a method that continues to work after publication -- is to have a dedicated branch for pre-audit code, and keep that branch only in internal repositories.  As soon as changes are approved, they can go to out to the public repository (on whatever branch is appropriate, presumably master).  Git makes this pretty easy; I have worked on projects that published to two repositories and it was fine.  One can set up hooks ("triggers" I guess git calls them) to make sure changes don't get published in the wrong repository just because someone made a typo when pushing, obviously.
@foxx and @SamMorrowDrums: As to whether GCHQ should be working more collaboratively, that's a separate question from publication, and I don't think we know enough to say whether they should be more collaborative or not.  It's not all upside, after all -- they might have good reasons for choosing one side of that tradeoff instead of the other.
More generally, I think there's often a mistaken impression that "open source" equals "collaborative development methodology".  The two don't always go together, and that's okay.  The only thing open source is definitely about is users' freedom to copy, customize, and redistribute the software as they see fit.  Whether a broadly collaborative development model makes sense for a particular project is a complicated question, and involves many more factors than just the license the software is under.
So I'm not making any assumptions about what reasons GCHQ has for not open-sourcing their code from Day One, nor about whether they should try for a more collaborative style of development.  However, I am emphasizing to @gaffer01 that one can put stuff in a public place starting from the earliest stages of development, without being under any obligation to change one's development methodology by taking on more collaborators.  While the latter would require the former, the former does not force the latter.
. Thanks, @gaffer01.  Looking forward to seeing it.
.
foxx:
@kfogel Most likely because the code has to be fully audited before being released, to ensure nothing is being leaked out to the public, and also to protect themselves against negative press (e.g. dodgy commit messages, leaked info etc). Github promotes social development, but this is the exact opposite of how GCHQ work, at least from an external standpoint, instead they are using Github as a release mechanism, rather than a development workflow tool. Shame really.

. Hi @sterkhedkar,
Maven is a tool used to build gaffer it can't be used to run gaffer.
In order to run gaffer you will need to create some “client” code,
I suggest you start by looking at the example folder in the project to get a feel for how to write code to interact with gaffer.
If you look at our simple query example here:
https://github.com/GovernmentCommunicationsHeadquarters/Gaffer/blob/master/example/src/main/java/gaffer/example/SimpleQuery.java
You can use this as a template for your own code.
We also have a getting started guide on a branch here:
https://github.com/GovernmentCommunicationsHeadquarters/Gaffer/blob/G14-user-guide/docs/getting_started.md
This relates to the example project and should introduce you to things like writing schemas for your data.
We are still working on a full user guide
Hope this helps.

. This is expected behaviour, 
The client side check on if both ends of an edge are valid for set retrievers executes on the client side to check that no incorrect Edges (Not within/between the sets) got through the bloom filter.
Calling .hasNext() without this check would simply be able to tell you if another Element existed in the accumulo scanner, not if there was a valid Element left.
If you were to call .next() and then do the check there, you could get the next Element, check to see if that Element was valid and then find that it wasn't, discard that Element but then find that the iterator has no more Elements left to check, whereupon you would be forced to return null or the last Element again, after the iterator having told you that there was another Element with the .hasNext() method.
However It can be made to behave more like a regular iterator with extra decision logic to scan ahead on a .next() call

. Hi ,
This performance seems slow to us especially the initial query, but we don't have enough information to diagnose the performance
We may be able to better tell you what's causing this if you could answer a few questions,
How many seeds are you using for your initial query?
What operations are you chaining together to do your depths?
How many results are you getting at each depth?
How are you querying Accumulo, through a rest-api or through a java app on the Accumulo cluster etc?
What kind of specifications do the Accumulo servers your running on have, are they virtual machines?
What are you using as your Identifiers? Are they Strings, Integers etc? And what serialiser did you choose as your Identifier Serialiser, in addition what serialisers are in use for your properties? 
The default serialisation for all items if not specified is java serialisation which is very slow which affects performance of querying heavily, its much better to choose serialisers appropriate for your data types from the simple-serialisation-library if you want performance.

I've cached the Connector object inside a store instance, meaning if you can maintain access to the same store instance like in an operation chain you only need to create the zkInstance once. The Connector object its-self can handle multiple threads/operations.
The zkInstance is still re-created if a new store instance is created (e.g by a second user) or the underlying getConnection method is called (currently all all but 1 calls pass through the getConnection method on the AccumuloStore class) this is worth keeping because it is good to check that the zookeeper nodes are still available in this case rather than relying on older connections.

. "What is the first edge returned, i.e. what does (A-B+A-C) mean, what is the source and what is the destination?"
Currently -> A-B+A-C will be the summarisation of the properties and the source and Destination will be those of the last key returned by the iterator.
"Is it possible to turn the behaviour described above off (and still do aggregation of the values over column family and visibility)?"
Not currently, you can't aggregate over column families anyway but I assume you meant qualifier 
When doing a range scan if you choose to summarise it will summarise over the provided Range. Grouping by column Family.
"Does this behaviour work across tablets? A-C might be in a different tablet (and on a different tablet server) to A-B. Does the aggregation work in this case?"
Currently all aggregation assumes that all data for the provided ranges lives on the same tablet server, client side aggregation is needed for all cases of aggregation to catch cases where the desired ranges are split across tablet servers.

. One Reason for the restriction is the avoidance of unnecessary parsing to find out if a given element is an Edge or Entity, for example in the accumulostore,  when aggregating properties the aggregation iterator takes the unique group name from the Column Family and knows for this key and Value Iterable how to deserialise the value into gaffer properties.
If group names were not unique it would also need to inspect the rowID to determine if the aggregator had the edge or entity to determine which property set the value should be deserialised too. The amount of work to inspect the rowID  would depends on the rowID structure (key-package) and may not be that much extra work, but it does add this extra processing.
. ## Migration Steps
This is a breaking change.
Problems with the previous method of serialisation in the provided KeyPackages means we have ceased support for the old method of serialisation into the Value/Column Qualifier of Accumulo going forward, if you have existing data it is advised to re-import this data into a new gaffer table using the new format, or write a map reduce job to convert the data from the old format to the new.
It is possible to re-implement the old key-packages if you want to migrate versions without migrating your data however this is not advised as this new method is more space efficient and performant, it is highly advised to migrate to the new key-packages as soon as possible.

. ## Migration Steps
The Versions of Accumulo and Hadoop have been changed to 1.7.2 and 2.6.3 respectively, while the codebase should still be compatible with the previous versions used we will no longer actively support them and the codebase may become incompatible with these versions at any point in the future.
It is advisable if possible to migrate any system running gaffer to the above versions going forward

. Closing issue, 
Instead of implementing a specific serialiser/function for a map type, 
We should instead enable generic map/set serialisation/Aggregation. # Migration steps
The old method of specifying serialisers has been deprecated, while still useable it is advisable to migrate as soon as is feasible.
If you had for example a storeType of prop.string previously you may have specified your serialiser like so : 
json
{
    "prop.string": {
        "serialiserClass" :  "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.serialisation.implementation.StringSerialiser",
        "aggregateFunction" : {
            "class": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.function.ExampleAggregateFunction"
        }
    }
}
Now you should specify the same like so:
json
{
    "prop.string": {
        "serialiser": {
            "class" : "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.serialisation.implementation.StringSerialiser"
        },
        "aggregateFunction" :  {
            "class": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.function.ExampleAggregateFunction"
        }
    } 
}

. The following changes have been applied in order to get codecov integration working:

A new profile has been created (-Ptravis), specifically for building Gaffer on Travis. This is required since the previous profile used in the Travis build process required setting the Maven Surefire plugin's forkCount property to 0, which breaks JaCoCo and prevents the test reports from being generated.
Since the forkCount property must be set to 1, the tests fail due to memory issues in the Travis containerised environment. To resolve this, fork reuse has been disabled and the amount of heap memory available to the Java process has been increased (-Xmx3072m).

If there are any issues with the Travis build process in future (entirely possible, as I'm not sure how marginal the build process is on memory at the moment), this approach may need to be revisited.. Closing, as this functionality is available by adding configuration to the MapContext object when creating the MapperGenerator.. Merged into develop

The method for specifying a splits file for Accumulo has changed.
The following options are required to set a splits file when carrying out a bulk import:

accumulostore.operation.hdfs.use_provided_splits_file - a boolean flag, set to the String "true" or "false" 
accumulostore.operation.hdfs.splits.file_path - String representing the file path to use

If "use_provided_splits_file" flag is true, the file path must be provided - this will be used to determine the splits.
If "use_provided_splits_file" flag is false, the file path must be provided - this will be used to determine where to write the generated splits file to.

. Current thinking for test strategy:

We will test against 3 different environments:
- Centos 7
- Debian 8
- Windows Server 2012
The following Java versions will be tested on each system:
- Java 7 (latest version available for each platform)
- Java 8 (latest version available for each platform)
This will allow us to support a very wide range of target environments, including Debian or RHEL derived systems.
A nightly build will be triggered to test all branches on all environments. This will also be used to carry out the release process to Maven Central.

The format of the Serialiser classes has changed. The serialisers are now generic classes, with the generic parameter being the type of object serialised and the target type for deserialisation.
The Serialiser classes are now also responsible for handling nulls. Default behaviour is provided by the AbstractSerialiser class, which should be extended. The default behaviour is to serialise null values as empty byte arrays and to deserialise empty byte arrays to null values again. In combination with the configuration for the Jackson ObjectMapper used, these null values will not be serialised when written as JSON.

. There are a couple of consequences to the changes that I've made here, so I'm happy to take suggestions if they cause more problems than they solve:
- Null handling behaviour is pushed down from the Accumulo Element converter to the individual serialiser classes. This is to provide enough flexibility to be able to discriminate between null values and empty (or default) values. An AbstractSerialiser class has been added which contains default handling for deserialising null values and for serialising empty values.
- Any Graphs which are created with a visibility property will always result in the visibility property being set on any elements retrieved from that Graph, even if the visibility contains an empty value.
- Element properties have been modified so that it is not permitted to create a property with a null key or a null value.

. # Migration Steps
In this issue the following operations have been deprecated:

GetRelatedElements
GetRelatedEdges
GetRelatedEntities
GetElementsBySeed
GetEdgesBySeed
GetEntitiesBySeed

These operations are still available, but will be removed entirely in a future version of Gaffer. These operations have been superseded by:

GetElements
GetEdges
GetEntities

each of which have properties which can be set to emulate the functionality of the removed operations.
The removed operations have also been removed from the REST API and are no longer displayed when view the Swagger UI. The REST endpoints representing these operations still exist, however, and will not result in any errors for the time being. As with the operations themselves, these REST endpoints will be removed in a future version of Gaffer.
All operation chains, workflows etc which depend on the deprecated operations should be migrated to the appropriate new operation.. Closing due to @gaffer01 's comments.. # Migration steps
Version 2 of the Gaffer REST API contains a number of changes which require user intervention.

The OperationChain class is now a subclass of Operation. In order for deserialisation to work correctly, any operation chains written in JSON and submitted to the REST API must contain the type ID in the JSON body. For example:

javascript
{
    "class" : "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.OperationChain",
    "operations" : [
        ...
    ]
}

Any users wanting to make use of the new API will be required to add a "v2" servlet to their web.xml file. For example,

```xml

Gaffer REST example v2
org.glassfish.jersey.servlet.ServletContainer
     

javax.ws.rs.Application

             uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.rest.application.ApplicationConfigV2
        


swagger.scanner.id
v2


swagger.config.id
v2

2
true


Gaffer REST example v2
/v2/*

```

The API now has four distinct sections:

|Resource|Description|
|---|---|
|/graph|The graph root resource|
|/graph/config|Resources relating to the graph configuration|
|/graph/jobs|Resources relating to submitting Jobs to the graph|
|/graph/operations|Resources relating to executing operations on the graph|
A full list of endpoints (with descriptions) is provided below:
Operations
|Method|Resource|Description|
|---|---|---|
|GET|/graph/operations|list of all operations supported by the current store|
|POST|/graph/operations/execute|perform the submitted operation|
|POST|/graph/operations/execute/chunked|perform the submitted operation|
|POST|/graph/operations/generate/elements|generate elements, as specified in the request body|
|POST|/graph/operations/generate/objects|generate objects, as specified in the request body|
|GET|/graph/operations/{className}|get information about the specified operation class|
|GET|/graph/operations/{className}/example|get an example JSON body for the specified operation class|
|GET|/graph/operations/{className}/next|list of all acceptable operations which can be performed after the specified operation|
Jobs
|Method|Resource|Description|
|---|---|---|
|POST|/graph/jobs|create a new job, based on the Operation contained in the request body|
|GET|/graph/jobs|get a list of all jobs|
|GET|/graph/jobs/{id}|get the details of the specified job|
|GET|/graph/jobs/{id}/results|get the results from running a job|
Configuration
|Method|Resource|Description|
|--|--|--|
|GET|/graph/config|get all configuration details|
|GET|   /graph/config/schema|get schema details|
|GET|/graph/config/filterFunctions|get filter function details|
|GET|/graph/config/filterFunctions/{inputClass}|get filter function details for given input class|
|GET|/graph/config/transformFunctions|get transform function details|
|GET|/graph/config/elementGenerators|get element generator details|
|GET|/graph/config/objectGenerators|get object generator details|
|GET|/graph/config/storeTraits|get store traits|
|POST|/graph/config/isOperationSupported|query the graph to see if a given operation is supported|
|GET|/graph/config/serialisedFields/{className}|get the serialised fields for a given class|
Status
|Method|Resource|Description|
|--|--|--|
|GET|/graph/status|get the graph status|. Closing to make some minor changes.

The following changes have been applied in order to get codecov integration working:

A new profile has been created (-Ptravis), specifically for building Gaffer on Travis. This is required since the previous profile used in the Travis build process required setting the Maven Surefire plugin's forkCount property to 0, which breaks JaCoCo and prevents the test reports from being generated.
Since the forkCount property must be set to 1, the tests fail due to memory issues in the Travis containerised environment. To resolve this, fork reuse has been disabled and the amount of heap memory available to the Java process has been increased (-Xmx3072m).

If there are any issues with the Travis build process in future (entirely possible, as I'm not sure how marginal the build process is on memory at the moment), this approach may need to be revisited.. Undirected edges are now created such that their source and destination vertices are ordered. This is carried out when an Edge object is created and should ensure a consistent representation of undirected Edges, removing the need for deduplication in external applications.
If the type of object used to represent vertices implements the Comparable interface, the provided compareTo(T obj) method is used to determine the ordering. The "smallest" object is chosen as the source. If the objects do not implement the Comparable interface, the toString() method is used instead.
It is highly recommended that classes which are to be used to represent vertices implement the Comparable interface. If this is not possible, then the classes should override the default toString() implementation to ensure consistent ordering. If neither of these steps are taken, then consistent ordering is not guaranteed, and users may be required to deduplicate undirected edges in their application.
The following methods relating to Element creation have been removed:
java
Edge.setSource
Edge.setDestination
Edge.setDirected
and have been replaced with:
java
Edge.setIdentifiers(source, destination, directed)
The return_matched_id_as_edge_source operation option that used to be available for GetElements operations on Accumulo and HBase has been removed. This option used to flip the edges around to ensure the source was the vertex that was matched by a seed. This produced edges that were invalid and misleading. So instead of flipping the Edges around the result Edges will now always have a matchedVertex field set specifying if the SOURCE or DESTINATION was matched. To allow chaining onto following operations we recommend using GetAdjacentIds instead or using ToVertices. ToVertices has been updated to allow you to ask for the matchedVertex to be extracted or the vertex opposite the matchedVertex to be extracted. See ToVerticesExample.. Merged into develop.. m316257:
This issue could be resolved like this:
- In the store schema we specify properties that can be used as 'group-by' keys for a reduce operation (group-by followed by aggregation)
- in some stores these group by keys are ordered (for example Accumulo), in others they are not (like a hadoop store where reduce operations are part of map-reduce and, in-principle, any property could be part of a key or a value)
- so in the store schema we no longer have mappings to 'positions', this is implicit in the ordering of the keys.
Additionally
- Security is promoted to being a top-level concept. Gaffer can do this as a filter operation. The idea being that in the store schema, a property can be marked as 'visibility' (or something similar).
- Some stores (such as accumulo) implement their own security. In this case, the actual implementation can be optimised by pushing it down to the store.
- by doing this we allow the grouping of reduce keys described above because if we specify visibilities per element we know that in accumulo these go in the visibility column. Any remaining group-by keys go in the column qualifier.
This should make the concept of reduce on a Gaffer graph a lot more general.
. I'm writing a schema and generators so that this comes with some pre-loaded data
. Closed based on suggestion from @d21211122 . Hi @supamanda 
This does seem a very long time compared to what i've experienced on AWS (a few minutes for similarly sized datasets). 
I've been using EMR, not EC2, and installing Gaffer-Accumulo using slider (https://github.com/gchq/gaffer-tools/tree/master/slider) I think the latency is most likely due to building a hadoop/spark/accumulo cluster from EC2 nodes. 
I'm guessing (but could be wrong) that the network bandwidth between EC2 nodes is not as good as between nodes in an EMR cluster.
I'd suggest, if possible, trying the same on a similarly sized EMR cluster. Thanks for the question. 
Gaffer is really designed for very large property graphs where the properties need to be summarised. 
A while ago we did experiment with RDF, SPARQL, OWL and Gaffer and concluded that it is possible. 
However, we don't have any plans in the near term to add or support this functionality ourselves. 
But of course we would be interested if you were thinking of experimenting with this and we are always open to contributions.. @maximveksler Sorry - we aren't aware of any production deployments of Gaffer/RDF/Sparql integrations..
okram:
I would recommend binding it via the Java API. That is, implement the following interfaces in TinkerPop:
Graph: https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/gremlin-core/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/structure/Graph.java
Vertex: https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/gremlin-core/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/structure/Vertex.java
VertexProperty: https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/gremlin-core/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/structure/VertexProperty.java
Edge: https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/gremlin-core/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/structure/Edge.java
Property: https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/gremlin-core/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/structure/Property.java
That is about 90% of the effort required. After that, to make things solid:
1. Connect it to the StructureStandardSuite and ProcessStandardSuite. You can see how this is done via TinkerGraph: https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/tinkergraph-gremlin/src/test/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/tinkergraph/structure/TinkerGraphStructureStandardTest.java and https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/tinkergraph-gremlin/src/test/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/tinkergraph/process/TinkerGraphProcessStandardTest.java
2. Add a TraversalStrategy to use index lookups. I assume you have fast lookups for stuff like "get me all vertices with name 'marko'." If so, then you will need something like TinkerGraphStepStrategy (https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/tinkergraph-gremlin/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/tinkergraph/process/traversal/strategy/optimization/TinkerGraphStepStrategy.java) where your GafferGraphStep implementation will use the HasContainers accordingly to do index lookups -- e.g. g.V().has('name','marko').
That is really all there is to it. I suspect a solid 1 week effort and you will then be able to use Gremlin to query your graph.
http://tinkerpop.apache.org/gremlin.html
Hope that helps.

@gaffer01
Thanks for the quick reply. There is another sketch already in the library that we are using actively at Yahoo that you might be interested in using: The HllMap. See our website for more info.  It is strictly for real-time tracking of unique IDs for many millions of keys.  We didn't have the need to ser-de, but if that is important, let us know.  
In addition to VarOpt, we have been considering PCA, K-means, and possibly wavelets, but generally moving into more vector-based sketching.  We are a tiny team and prioritization is largely based on feedback and sound use cases (and published theoretical proofs of error bounds :) )  So your participation in our emerging community would be appreciated. 
The PR DataSketches/sketches-core#142 is being actively worked on. 
. @gaffer01 

The comments on HLLMap say that it is optimized for many millions of keys - does it have any advantages if the number of keys is small, e.g. if there was a need to store several (<5) HLLs on each node, would HLLMap offer a storage advantage over just storing a map from key to HLL?

The short answer is no. Don't use the HllMap for small key counts.
I don't pretend to understand all of your use case specifics, but allow me to imagine a scenario where the HllMap might make sense:  Suppose you have a potentially large graph with 100M nodes (perhaps IP addresses or Geo Where-on-earth IDs) and unique (user or edge) identifiers, which can be associated dynamically to a node in real time.  You would like to be able to monitor, also in real-time, the number of unique (user or edge) IDs that is associated with each node.  
Instead of having a sketch at each node, you have a central server (which receives all the incoming traffic) which would contain a single HllMap.  Assume for simplicity, an identifier is a fixed length number (like an IP-address or a geo-identifier).  The HllMap is updated dynamically with each incoming node ID and user ID.  Since it is a map, you can query the HllMap at any time and get the unique count of user ID.  
Now it is also possible to scan the entire map (in a single pass) at any time using a Quantiles Sketch and obtain the PMF or CDF distribution of Users per node.  You could also scan the map with the Frequent Items Sketch and get the list of IDs of the heavy-hitter nodes.
The economy of storage comes with the assumption that the distribution of edges (or users) per node is very skewed (as is usually the case with human traffic) and that the overhead of the machinery of the sketch is amortized because it is all in one instance.  Such an HllMap sketch would typically be large (on the order of a GB or so, but when you compute the cost per node it is far smaller than having a sketch per node.   In our applications with 100M nodes and our traffic distributions, after subtracting the storage required for the keys, the storage allocated for unique counting per node is about 10 bytes.   And the accuracy (RSE) (using this specific HllMap) is about 2.6%.  Which was more than good enough for our application.

it seems that the length of the key must be fixed.

Yes it is true.  The HllMap was designed for fixed length keys (identifiers), which was critical for efficient map storage and speed.  You could use strings converted to bytes, assuming the string keys have a maximum length.  Having arbitrary length keys would make the entire HllMap much much larger and much slower.  

HLlSketch seems to serialize to 73 bytes even if nothing has been added to it. 

The HllSketch has a number of configuration options, but let me look into it.  I think it can be even smaller, but let me get back here with some specifics.
. @gaffer01 
One more comment:

It is crucial for the serialization of a HLL which is almost empty to be very efficient.

Absolutely.  And this is how all of our sketches have been designed.
All of our sketches have a "warm-up" mode where the sketch starts out very small and grows larger only as required by the data.  An empty Theta Sketch is only 8 bytes stored.
Some sketches reach a maximum size that is never exceeded (the (Theta, Sampling, and FrequentItems sketches), while others may not have a maximum size (Quantiles and HllMap).  The Quantile Sketch grows logarithmically and for most use cases is much smaller than a Theta Sketch, which has an upper bound in size.  The HllMap grows, of course, largely based on the number of keys. 
The HllSketch starts out with a tiny hash table of "coupons" and then expands to the full HLL array only when it makes sense.  The HllMap also has a "warm-up" strategy that has multiple stages in order to keep the overall storage very efficient, but it's start-up size is considerably bigger than the other sketches.. @gaffer01
I just noticed in your comment above that you may be assuming that the HllMap internally uses the same HllSketch available in the library.  It does not.  The form of the HLL sketch internally has been specially designed for this mapping application.  It is a bit too complex to describe here, but but of all the different HLL sketches in the library, the one in the HllMap is the most efficient during warmup ( I. E. When the unique counts are very small.  For example, early on, each entry adds only the key and 2 bytes for each new unique update.  . @gaffer01

This is because within our team when we refer to the UniqueCountMap we call it the HllMap sketch because the key internal algorithm is HLL and it is a Map.   But the actual class that pulls it all together is the UniqueCountMap.   Sorry about the confusion, my mistake.. I want to return to your question about space usage and introduce some refinements in our terminology with respect to sketch size and memory space utilization.
Sketch size
Most of our sketches have a configuration parameter k, or NominalEntries,  that affects both the memory requirements of the sketch as well as its accuracy.   k generally refers to the number of entries that the sketch needs to retain in order to guarantee related accuracy bounds.  The size of an entry however, depends on the chosen sketch.  For the Theta Sketches all update values are hashed to a 64-bit long, so an entry is 8 bytes. For the Quantiles, FrequentItems, and Sampling sketches an item can be some arbitrary object defined by the user. And since these objects are retained by the sketch, the overall memory consumed is directly dependent on the item size.
Updatable vs Compact (immutable) Memory Size
Most of the sketches have (at least) two forms of internal data structures.  The Updatable form uses either a set of lists or a hash table that expands as required by incoming data and thus requires some extra overhead in space to enable high performance updating.  The Compact form is designed for read-only operations where no more updating of the sketch is anticipated.  In this form the extra space overhead required for an updating sketch can be eliminated.  Depending on the sketch, and the internal state, the Compact form can be half the size of the Updatable sketch. When multiplied by millions or billions of sketches being stored, a 50% savings is space required can be substantial.  Some of the sketches allow the user to specify during serialization, whether the resulting image is in the updatable or compact form.
On-heap vs Off-heap sketches.
In large system environments where a single machine can have 500GB RAM and 24 cores, much of that RAM space is often dedicated to memory-mapped files for fast query performance.  When the sketch image is stored off-heap it is usually in compact form, data only, which means there is no Java Object overhead included.  What remains in the Java heap is a "Direct" Sketch that is just a small shell wrapper that has a pointer to the off-heap sketch image of the data that it uses to query results.  
Currently only two of the sketch families, Theta and Quantiles, have off-heap (Direct) forms that actually can be updated off-heap.  Some of the other sketches can support operations via a "heapify" operation, which brings the off-heap data on-heap. 
Now back to the question about the serialization size of the HllSketch.  If an empty HllSketch has been compacted, it will serialize to 9 bytes.  If not compacted, (i.e., in updatable form) it serializes to 86 bytes.  This is because to be updatable it reserves space for 16 potential "coupons" (the temporary form of the HLL entries prior to the full HLL table being created) plus a few other registers required for the update process.  The first 11 or 12 entries just fill the potential coupon space thus the space required does not increase.  Meanwhile, if compacted, each of these entries add 4 bytes to the compact form.  So the stored, compacted images would have a size of 9, 13, 17, 21, ... bytes until the sketch converts to the full HLL array.  Then the size depends on the chosen logK for the sketch and whether the compressed form of the sketch (4-bit buckets) or naive dense form (8-bit buckets) is chosen.  
I hope this helps.

. @gaffer01 
This is very helpful insight into your requirements.

compact serialization for the low cardinality case is particularly important.

We agree, and we have taken great pains to make this true.

Ideally the sketch should provide accurate estimates for both low cardinalities and high cardinalities.

For all sketches (HLL, Theta, Frequent Items, Quantiles, Sampling) the accuracy estimates for low number of entries are better than when the sketches transition into full estimation mode.  In fact,  in most cases, the estimation errors are zero up to some threshold, which is a function of the configured k.  HLL is more complex as it has multiple estimators based on cardinality zones.  The lowest zone (up to a cardinality of about 8 or 16 has practically zero error. 

It's worth noting that for large-scale graphs a small sketch size might be chosen at the expense of accuracy, i.e. prioritize small serialized size over the accuracy of the sketch.

Two comments here. 


Be careful.  If you choose a small k for large-scale graphs and a larger k for small-scale graphs ... AND you wish to be able to merge these sketches together the resulting accuracy will always be determined by the small k.   There are some subtle exceptions to this (but not with HLL).  So if merging of mixed k sketches is very common, you may as well choose space or accuracy to determine k, and stick with it for all scales.


If you have millions to billions of sketches in storage and you are concerned about the aggregate storage of all these sketches, AND your cardinality distribution is power-law, you might consider using the p-sampling option of the Theta Sketches.  This allows you to reduce the aggregate storage of all the sketches by factors of ~ 1/p, and maintain the same accuracy for the largest cardinality sketches (but the accuracy of queries against the smallest nodes can be considerably worse).  This works well if you can make the assumption that your queries are mostly concerned with the big guys.  We have experimented with p values as low as 0.1 (thus total space is reduce by about 10) with good results for the vast majority of queries.  With these assumptions, Theta Sketches in aggregate, can consume less space than HLL sketches.  But you will have to experiment with your actual data distributions and query distributions to see if this works for you or not.



If the HLL implementation could be extended so that it allowed merging of the compact sketches, that would make it a lot more useful for this application.

That is always the plan.

Presumably by "advanced estimators" you're referring to the improvements in the HyperLogLog++ paper?

The HLL++ papers refer to compressing the HLL encoding array down to 4-bits, which can be done several ways.  But we haven't found any really good (or correct) implementations out there.  We have come up with what we think is superior in many ways to the HLL++ paper, both in terms of accuracy, size and speed performance.  We also leverage the HIP estimator, when appropriate, which was proposed by Edith Cohen a few years ago.  We also have developed advanced estimators for the low and intermediate cardinality zones that has not yet been published (coming soon). 

One use case for the theta sketches would be to understand the evolution of the graph over time.

This is what we call retention analysis, and we have it in production in many of our systems, where the time interval resolution is often hours, days, weeks or months, chosen by the user.
One application you didn't mention, which we have used to great success, is near-real-time use of sketching.  We currently have systems deployed with real-time query results within seconds of real time.

& 2. Yes. Internally, the sketch starts as a simple list of "coupons", then transitions to a hash table of coupons, then at ~ 3/4 * 2^(log2(k) - 3), which is about 10% of k, transitions to the full HLL array, which thereafter is constant in size (except for the 4-bit version, which in very very rare cases might need to grow a few percent.  The word "coupon" comes from the famous "Coupon Collector Problem", which is very close to how an HLL sketch behaves early on.  Our coupons are 4 bytes each.


& 4. Not perfect, but better than anything in the literature.  This is our new estimator for the HLL low range.  The RSE is less than 50 ppm and is independent of K and independent of the Target HLL Type.  BTW, the accuracy for all 3 types is the same for the same LgK, as they are all isomorphic to each other.  The accuracy of unioning is also independent of the incoming sketch type, and you can union sketches of different lgK.

This is great feedback, thank you!  I will make some comments and try to answer the questions you have:

For any sketch that we use we need to be able to serialise it to a byte array for storage. Later we need to be able to deserialise it (a) back to the sketch to obtain whatever estimates the sketch provides, (b) to merge it with another deserialised sketch. Of course this serialisation and deserialisation can be relatively expensive, but as some of our stores (e.g. the Accumulo and Hbase ones) are designed for large-scale storage, it is not always viable to leave the sketches in memory. Streaming jobs can be used to aggregate sketches over a time window before they are serialised and stored, but the requirement to deserialise them later and possibly merge with other sketches of the same type remains.

Sketch uses after deserialization.  You mentioned (a) get estimate and (b) merging, but you didn't mention (c) continue updating the sketch.  Do you ever have this 3rd use case?  If so, and depending on the sketch, one must pay attention to the serialized form.  More on this later if you need it.
Serialization & deserialization costs.  What I can't tell from your comments is your requirements on query latency.  We also have massive data that has been stored in sketch form (on disk) that goes back several years.  Based on the breadth and depth of the query, of course, even in sketch form it can sometimes take a minute (from a Hadoop environment) to bring the relevant sketches (sometimes millions) into memory so they can be merged with more recent sketches.  Still, careful profiling of the queries and staging of history allows us to keep more than 95% of the query latencies under a second.  
This query latency is also very sensitive to the design of your back-end store.  While Hadoop (HBase) offers large distributed storage, for some of our most critical latency requirements we find HBase too slow.   For our real-time systems, we use a combination of Storm and Druid.  A typical Druid cluster might have 100 nodes, each node with 256- 512GB RAM and 48 hyperthreads.  All of this RAM is used for data and the JVM, which acts as a supervisor, may only be 8GB. The data in RAM is paged in as required from SSDs. This is where the Memory package from our library comes into play.  So far, two of our sketches, Theta and Quantiles, take full advantage of this by being able to operate directly from off-heap memory.  (We will be adding an Direct (or off-heap) extension to the HLL sometime soon.).  This largely eliminates the need to be constantly serializing and deserializing the sketches.  It takes quite a bit of care and engineering at the system level to make this all work, but the real-time query results are truly amazing. In this environment we routinely merge millions of sketches and provide sub-second query latency.  

Question: Would it be more efficient to use the static method unionImpl on Union to merge the two Unions (but this method is not public so presumably it is not intended to be used by external code)?

There is no UnionImpl method in the HLL Union. Perhaps you captured a pre-release version that had that method (perhaps I called it that at one point, but now it is called 'gadget').   Nonetheless, the non-public members behind the HLL Union must not be directly accessed by users for good reasons,  one of which is that these members can be swapped out entirely during the unioning process, so attempting to keep a link to these private members would be futile.  And no, it would not be faster, and even if you could make it work, it could be catastrophically slower.

It seems that there is no toByteArray directly on Union, unlike the reservoir sampling package?

I will talk to my colleague who worked on this and get back to you.  We had a good reason, I just don't recall at the moment the details.
The rest of your use-cases seem well thought out.  . @gaffer01 

I was looking at the unionImpl static method on line 199 of https://github.com/DataSketches/sketches-core/blob/sketches-core-0.10.0/src/main/java/com/yahoo/sketches/hll/Union.java, but you've answered my question anyway thanks.

I am red-faced on this one, and I wrote it!  
This static method examines the state of the current internal gadget and the incoming sketch and determines the optimum way to perform the union. This may involve swapping, down-sampling, transforming, and / or copying one of the arguments and may completely replace the internals of the union.  
The result is always in HLL_8 form, which may not be what the user wants. In general, it is not safe for a user to have a reference to the internal data structures, which could be changed by the user, or the reference may get completely replaced by later union operations.

12% error seems anomalous

This is well within 95% confidence interval, which is about 18% for HLL(7).
. Could you help us understand why you are associating union objects instead of sketch objects with your vertices or edges? Unions are typically larger than sketches. In case of HLL family, unions are always in 8-bit mode, but sketches can be in 4-bit mode, which is the most compact mode, and is the default mode.
In case of Theta family, Union contains an UpdateSketch as its internal state. Do you update your vertices and edges? If not, the associated Theta sketch can be in the compact form.
By the way, the Theta family has PairwiseSetOperations if you just want to produce a union of two sketches as opposed to performing a massive union operation on thousands or millions of sketches, for which Unions are designed.. > In the first approach, we need to call getResult() once and update once. In the second we need to create a new Union, call update twice and then call getResult().
The first update of an empty union is simple. Most probably there is no performance penalty compared to the second approach. It seems to me that this perceived simplicity of the first approach doesn't justify larger serialized blob. Serialized unions are larger (sometimes much larger) than sketches. Especially if sketches can be stored in a compact form.

There was also some issue, which I can't remember in detail, about some of the sketches
not being updateable once they have been serialised to a compact form.

As I understood from your other comment "once a sketch has been serialised, it only changes when it is merged with another sketch". So converting sketches to  a compact form must be desirable..

NamedViews
The code for this example is NamedViews.
This example explains how to configure your Gaffer Graph to allow NamedViews to be used. Named views enable encapsulation of a View, or multiple Views, into a new single NamedView. A NamedView can be used in conjunction with other Views. There are various possible uses for NamedViews, including:

Making it simpler to reuse frequently used Views.
Share commonly used Views with other users.

In addition to the NamedView there are a set of operations which manage named views (AddNamedView, GetAllNamedViews, DeleteNamedView).
Configuration
You will need to configure what cache to use for storing NamedViews. For more information on the cache service, see Cache.
Using Named Views
Please note; If you want to change the region for NamedViews you can do so by specifying it within the cache.ccf file using region jcs.region.namedViewsRegion.
We will now go through some examples using NamedViews.
We will use the same basic schema and data from the first developer walkthrough.
Start by creating your user instance and graph:
final User user = new User("user01");
final Graph graph = new Graph.Builder()
        .config(getDefaultGraphConfig())
        .addSchemas(StreamUtil.openStreams(getClass(), schemaPath))
        .storeProperties(getDefaultStoreProperties())
        .build();
Then add a NamedView to the cache with the AddNamedView operation:
```
final AddNamedView addNamedView = new AddNamedView.Builder()
        .name("RoadUse edges")
        .description("NamedView to get only RoadUse edges")
        .view(new View.Builder()
                .edge("RoadUse")
                .build())
        .overwrite(false)
        .build();
graph.execute(addNamedView, user);
```
For the next step we need to create a GetElements operation and use the NamedView previously added to the cache, using the name specified. After this we can execute it:
```
final GetElements operation = new GetElements.Builder()
        .view(new NamedView.Builder()
                .name("RoadUse edges")
                .build())
        .input(new EntitySeed("10"))
        .build();
final CloseableIterable<? extends Element> namedViewResults = graph.execute(operation, user);
The results are:
Edge[source=10,destination=11,directed=true,matchedVertex=SOURCE,group=RoadUse,properties=Properties[endDate=Mon May 01 23:59:59 BST 2000,count=2,startDate=Mon May 01 00:00:00 BST 2000]]
Edge[source=10,destination=11,directed=true,matchedVertex=SOURCE,group=RoadUse,properties=Properties[endDate=Tue May 02 23:59:59 BST 2000,count=1,startDate=Tue May 02 00:00:00 BST 2000]]
Edge[source=11,destination=10,directed=true,matchedVertex=DESTINATION,group=RoadUse,properties=Properties[endDate=Wed May 03 23:59:59 BST 2000,count=1,startDate=Wed May 03 00:00:00 BST 2000]]
```
NamedViews can also take parameters, allowing values to be configured by the user when the NamedView is used. When adding a NamedView with parameters the View must be specified as a JSON string, with parameter names enclosed with '${' and '}'. For each parameter, a ViewParameterDetail object must be created which gives a description, a class type and an optional default for the Parameter, and also indicates whether the parameter must be provided (ie. there is no default).
The following code adds a NamedView with a 'countIsMoreThan' parameter that allows the minimum edge count for the View to be set, along with a 'selectionParam' parameter that allows the user to set the selection for the View:
String viewString = "{" +
        "      \"edges\" : {" +
        "        \"RoadUse\" : {  " +
        "           \"preAggregationFilterFunctions\" : [ {" +
        "               \"predicate\" : {" +
        "                   \"class\" : \"uk.gov.gchq.koryphe.impl.predicate.IsMoreThan\"," +
        "                   \"orEqualTo\" : false," +
        "                     \"value\": {" +
        "                         \"java.lang.Long\" : \"${isMoreThanParam}\"" +
        "                       }" +
        "                 }," +
        "             \"selection\" : [ \"${selectionParam}\" ]" +
        "         } ] }" +
        "      }," +
        "      \"entities\" : { }" +
        "}";
```
ViewParameterDetail param = new ViewParameterDetail.Builder()
        .description("Selection param")
        .valueClass(String.class)
        .required(true)
        .build();
ViewParameterDetail param1 = new ViewParameterDetail.Builder()
        .description("isMoreThan param")
        .defaultValue(0L)
        .valueClass(Long.class)
        .build();
Map paramDetailMap = Maps.newHashMap();
paramDetailMap.put("selectionParam", param);
paramDetailMap.put("isMoreThanParam", param1);
final AddNamedView addNamedViewWithParams = new AddNamedView.Builder()
        .name("customCountView")
        .description("named View with count param")
        .view(viewString)
        .parameters(paramDetailMap)
        .overwrite(false)
        .build();
graph.execute(addNamedViewWithParams, user);
A view can then be created, with a value provided for the 'countIsMoreThan' and 'selectionParam' parameter:
Map paramMap = Maps.newHashMap();
paramMap.put("selectionParam", "count");
paramMap.put("isMoreThanParam", 1L);
final GetElements operationUsingParams = new GetElements.Builder()
        .view(new NamedView.Builder()
                .name("customCountView")
                .parameters(paramMap)
                .build())
        .input(new EntitySeed("10"))
        .build();
and executed:
final CloseableIterable<? extends Element> namedViewResultsWithParams = graph.execute(operationUsingParams, user);
giving these results:
Edge[source=10,destination=11,directed=true,matchedVertex=SOURCE,group=RoadUse,properties=Properties[endDate=Mon May 01 23:59:59 BST 2000,count=2,startDate=Mon May 01 00:00:00 BST 2000]]
```

OLD:
{
   "class": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.impl.get.GetElements",
    "seedMatching": "EQUAL",
      "input": [
      {
         "class": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.data.EdgeSeed",
         "source": “source1“,
         "destination": “dest1“,
         "directed": "true"
      }
   ]
}
NEW:
{
   "class": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.impl.get.GetElements”,
      "input": [
      {
         "class": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.data.EdgeSeed",
         "source": “source1“,
         "destination": “dest1”,
         "directed": "true"
      }
   ],
   "view" : {
    "edges": {
      “group1“:{}
    }
  }
}
For entities it should now be written:
OLD:
{
   "class": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.impl.get.GetElements",
    "seedMatching": "EQUAL",
      "input": [
      {
         "class": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.data.EntitySeed",
         "vertex": “vertex1”
      }
   ]
}
NEW:
{
  "class" : "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.impl.get.GetElements",
  "input" : [ {
    "class" : "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.data.EntitySeed",
    "vertex" : “vertex1”
  } ],
  "view" : {
    "entities": {
      “group1“: {}
    }
  }
}

Thanks, your explanation makes sense.. 1 - Unfortunately I can't go into the specific use-case.  In general the issue arises when there are a subset of the properties that are metadata about the element which can be used to determine how many of the other properties are to be aggregated. One example is timestamp but there can be others.  The non-timestamp properties will be in the schema's groupBy so that the data is not lost and can be queried on if necessary.  However there are many times we don't want to query on the metadata, but rather just want it used to provide the aggregated results of the non-metadata properties.  Hope that helps.  This can all be solved by bundling the metadata properties into each non-metdata property whos aggregation it affects, however it would be nice if that wasn't the necessary.  Thanks for pointing me to the First operator, as it would make sense to use that in situations where we will not change the groupBy and just need the timestamp for aggregation.

The comments say you can change the validationFunction and the aggregateFunction, and you mentioned you can add an element group.  That makes sense that it would be just an iterator change.  Specifically, would there be any issues in me adding a new property (whether groupBy or not) to an existing element group?  I understand that something like changing the groupBy list on an existing element group would likely require me writing a map-reduce job or an export/import of some kind.

I've been doing as you said, bundling them all in a property together.  Essentially I have a couple properties that affect how the rest of the properties get aggregated.  Instead of duplicating each property in all of the rest and writing a custom type for all them it's been easier making them all one property.
An example might be timestamp and prop1 affect the others (int, double, date...), so the options are:


Write serializers & aggregators for each bundled property: (timestamp, prop1, int), (timestamp, prop1, double), (timestamp, prop1, date)....


Write one serializer & aggregator for (timestamp, prop1, int, double, date...) and put them in one property


I've gone with the later option for now.  Don't know that it's a problem, but doesn't seem ideal.  Aggregating multiple properties with one function would be nice.  This would avoid having to duplicate the data throughout the properties or collapse them all into one giant property.  Again, might be more trouble than it's worth to implement, don't know.
